mxCell.value: Nice to meet you!

<<Accounts>>

Welcome to MyBudgetCoach, [[user_first_name]]! This is a unique budgeting program with built-in support. Thank you for choosing me, Kristin Wade, as your personal coach.

<<Accounts>>

This can be a lot to learn! That's why you can schedule time with me using this button. Feel free to tap me in whenever you want a real person to talk to.

And don't worry, I can't see you budget unless you share your password with me. It's all private.
highlight: zoom_link
What's that?<br style="border-color: var(--border-color);">done_zero_based = no

Yes
done_zero_based = yes
No thanks!

<<Accounts>>

You'll find that MyBudgetCoach may have a similar feel to your old system. What's the difference? You have support throughout your financial journey with me, your personal coach.
Old school, nice

<<Accounts>>

It's time to get started! Feel free to take a break whenever you need. If you close the browser, I'll be here to pick up where you left off.
Got it!

<<Accounts>>

Please note: one-on-one coaching has an additional hourly fee on top of your monthly membership fee. You get a discounted rate for my budget coaching services!
I'm Ready!

<<Accounts>>

Let's take the first step to finding budget bliss! Here's the tutorial we'll walk through together:

1. Account Tour & Setup
2. How to Add Transactions
3. Budget Tour & Setup
4. Budget Skills
I Renamed My Budget

<<Accounts>>

Everything is custom here, so let's start with what you'll call your budget.
Click on the arrow and select "Rename Budget." Then pick a name for your shiny new budget. Make sure to click "Enter" on your keyboard.

You can change this later if you want!
highlight: budget_name
I'm all ears ðŸŒ½

It's just me!
budget_with_partner = just_me

With a partner, but our finances are separate.
budget_with_partner = partner_seperate

With a partner and with joint finances.
budget_with_partner = partner_joint

<<Accounts>>

Are you budgeting alone or with a partner?

<<Accounts>>

Let's keep digging so I can better understand your current financial organization.

Only one
account_structure = only_one

3 or More
account_structure = more_than_three

<<Accounts>>

How many checking accounts do you have and actively use?
Let's do this!

<<Accounts>>

Look at that, we're already getting to know each other! Let's add your main checking account.
Nice, I can revisit when I need

<<Accounts>>

This virtual coach will walk you through the setup tutorial. It's not a chat bot and can't answer your questions directly. You can click the back button to review as needed. Or you can click "Manage Coach" to reset me and go back to the start of the tutorial.
Oh, really?

<<Accounts>>

It's common to have multiple accounts! It can be a bit tricky to manage at first in MyBudgetCoach.
I'm tracking

<<Accounts>>

If you add multiple positive accounts (savings or checking), they will be put into the same pile to budget.
A $500 savings account and a $1,000 checking account will show that you have $1,500 to budget.

<<Accounts>>

While this IS true, just make sure you have your dollars separated. While you have $1,500 to budget in this scenario, you couldn't write a check for $1,500 without first moving money around.
I can see that

<<Accounts>>

Don't worry, we'll cover this later! If it sounds overwhelming right now you can just add a single account to start.
Account Setup

<<Accounts>>

I love that you're in it together! So I can get to know you better, what's your partner's name?
Multiple Accounts<br style="border-color: var(--border-color);">joint_accounts = multiple

Next
partners_name = [user_input]

<<Accounts>>

Want to check out the program without my face popping up? Just hit the X on the top left and I get tucked away. You can bring me back by clicking "Continue Conversation" under my picture.
Got it!

<<Accounts>>

Each envelope is labeled with a purpose. Rent, groceries, cell phone bill, date night, etc. You stuff those envelopes with the money from payday.

<<Accounts>>

When your stack of cash has run out, that means no more money can go into envelopes. You either have to wait until the next payday, re-allocate some dollars, or not spend in that area.

<<Accounts>>

Imagine the same scenario, but in the digital world. Partly because it's dangerous to have that much cash on you, and mostly because it's way more convenient this way.
Can't wait to learn more!

<<Accounts>>

We are only going to budget the dollars you have right now in your account. No planning for future paychecks. Instead of envelopes, we use categories. More on this later!

I sure do! ðŸ’°

Nope
savings_account = no

<<Accounts>>

Lastly, do you have a savings account?

Nope
savings_account = no

<<Accounts>>

Lastly, do you have a savings account?

2
account_structure = two

I sure do! ðŸ’°
savings_account = yes

<<Accounts>>

MyBudgetCoach will show you how to manage your money in a new way than you may be used to. I want you to imagine all of your money is in cash. You're sitting at your dining room table with a stack of envelopes.

Single Account
joint_accounts = single

<<Accounts>>

I like it, [[user_first_name]]! Before we get too far, I have a few questions to better guide your setup experience.
highlight: add_account
Done, coach!

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account." 
1. Pick a name, "Checking" works for now
2. Select "For Budget: Checking"
3. Keep the current balance as $0 for now 
3. Click "Create" to finish

<<Accounts>>

Ready?
Select + Add Account!

<<Accounts>>

While you're learning, select just your main credit card to add. Once you get the hang of things we can add others if you have them.

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account." 
1. Pick a name, "Credit Card" works for now
2. Select "For Budget: Credit Card"
3. Keep the current balance as $0 for now
3. Click "Create" to finish

<<Accounts>>

Ready? Select + Add Account!

No
credit_cards = no

Yes ðŸ’³
credit_cards = yes

<<Accounts>>

Let's keep going. Do you have credit cards that you use regularly?
I'll keep that in mind!

<<Accounts>>

Credit cards are a personal preference! I support clients with whichever financial products they choose. If you want to add a credit card later, it's as simple as adding your checking account.
Ooh, choices

<<Accounts>>

You'll see three options here. MyBudgetCoach has partnered with GoCardless (for European banks) and SimpleFin (US) to link to your bank and import transactions.

<<Accounts>>

Pros: automatic importing of your transactions to save you time

Cons: additional setup and an additional fee for SimpleFin.
Deal ðŸ¤

<<Accounts>>

I recommend starting with manual entry of your transactions. Budgeting is overwhelming enough, so this is how I like to start my clients. 

We can always link your accounts later when you get the hang of budgeting.
Account Navigation
I'm trusting the process!

<<Accounts>>

One step down! It's time for a tour of what this account screen looks like. 
You may be chomping at the bit to get to the budget, but we're building a foundation together. Bear with me! ðŸ»
Let's go!

<<Accounts>>

You're doing great! Now I'm going to give you a little tour of your account screen.
I've selected it

<<Accounts>>

Let's make sure you're in your checking account. Click into your checking account if you aren't there already.
I opened it up

<<Accounts>>

Below the name you can see the account balance. Click here to see a breakdown of the uncleared and cleared totals.
highlight: account_balance
The suspense is killing me!

<<Accounts>>

I'll give more explanation as to why this is important later.
highlight: import_button

<<Accounts>>

If you don't choose to link your account with SimpleFin, you can either manually enter transactions one-by-one or upload a file from your bank. Uploading a file takes a few extra steps, but it saves you time to batch transactions.
How neat!

<<Accounts>>

This button lets you upload a QIF, OFX or QFX file of your bank transactions. If you want more help with this, we can do it on a Zoom call together.
highlight: add_new_button

<<Accounts>>

This is where you manually add new transactions for this account.
highlight: filter_button

<<Accounts>>

The Filter button lets you view transactions based on certain criteria you set. Click it to view your options.
highlight: search_bar

<<Accounts>>

The search bar helps you find transactions based on date, category, transaction amount or payee. This will come in handy when you're digging through hundreds of transactions looking for something specific ðŸ”
highlight: split_toggle_button
That checks out

<<Accounts>>

Sometimes you'll have a "split" transaction. Like those times you go to Target and buy both groceries AND household supplies.

<<Accounts>>

With MyBudgetCoach, you can enter this purchase as one transaction but split under two (or more) categories. It even helps you with the math. You'll get to practice!

<<Accounts>>

These arrows allow you to expand or collapse split transactions. You can collapse them for a cleaner view, or leave them open for the full picture. Since you don't have a split transaction, it won't do anything just yet.
highlight: more_button
Boy, that's a lot of options

<<Accounts>>

You've got even more options here. Click this and let's explore.

<<Accounts>>

By clicking "Show running balance", a new column is added to the right. This shows the account balance after each transaction occurs. This will come in handy when we're making sure your account balances are accurate.

<<Accounts>>

"Hide 'cleared' checkboxes" removes the column that shows the cleared (green) and uncleared (grey) checkboxes next to your transactions. Think of these as reminders of what has cleared in your bank vs. what is still pending.

<<Accounts>>

With "Export" you can download all of your transactions as a CSV file here. Great if you're into data, but not necessary for most users.

<<Accounts>>

"Reconcile" is a fancy word for making sure you're budgeting the right amount of dollars! It's important to regularly check your bank account and add transactions. Reconciling is a fancy term for "does my budget account match my bank account in real life."

<<Accounts>>

Remember when I talked about the pros and cons of linking your account? If you decide to go for it, you'll use "Link Account" in this menu to do so! No need to delete and re-add the account. ðŸ”—

<<Accounts>>

"Close account": If you need to get this account out of MyBudgetCoach, this is where you can delete it. Note: this button won't affect your actual bank accounts in real life.

<<Accounts>>

That concludes the tour of your account page! Remember, you can take a break and come back if needed. You're doing great!

<<Accounts>>

Mistakes happen, so if you want to quickly Undo or Redo an action, those buttons live next to "Filter."
Add Transaction
Checking, check!

<<Accounts>>

Quite the tour, I know! We're moving on and you get to try some skills out.

We're going to practice adding transactions to your account. Start by verifying you are still in your checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Next, click on "+ Add New"
Got my Payee entered

<<Accounts>>

Now click on "Payee" and enter "Grocery Store." Since we're starting from scratch, click "+ Create New Payee."
highlight: select_payee
highlight: add_new_button

<<Accounts>>

For now, leave the Note blank. That's a great spot to leave a memo for yourself.
Mmmm, now I'm hungry.

<<Accounts>>

Click on Category and select Food. You can type "F" and it will filter through the budget categories. You can also scroll through the category choices.
highlight: select_category
$50 entered, ouch

<<Accounts>>

Since you spent money, it's considered Payment. Type in $50 in that box.
highlight: payment_input
I added the transaction!

<<Accounts>>

To save this transaction, click Add.
highlight: save_transaction

<<Accounts>>

Great job! You've added your first transaction. Now, lets take a look at some other elements on here.
highlight: cleared_status_icon

<<Accounts>>

When you add a new transaction, the system defaults to "Uncleared." This checkbox is grey and means the transaction has not cleared in your bank account yet.
I cleared the transaction

<<Accounts>>

Let's pretend you checked your account and voila! The transaction has cleared. Click this box to turn it green and "Clear" the transaction.
Canceled the next transaction

<<Accounts>>

Notice that once you add one transaction, MyBudgetCoach assumes you immediately want to add another one. For now, click cancel to move forward.

<<Accounts>>

Let's try this again with money coming into your account. Keep in mind any income received will be entered as a deposit including refunds and rebates.
Paycheck entered!

<<Accounts>>

For this example enter this data and click Add.
 Payee: Employer
Category: Income
Deposit Amount: $500

You can scroll or type "I" to find the Income category.
The pressure is on!

<<Accounts>>

You're getting the hang of this, so I'll be over here guiding you. I believe in you!

Start by clicking + Add New.

<<Accounts>>

Now you can see two transactions, one is cleared and one is not. Click on Account Balance.
It's all cleared!

<<Accounts>>

The Uncleared balance is $500. Now, click on the grey checkmark for the paycheck transaction you just entered. This clears it and turns it green.

<<Accounts>>

Why does this matter? Let's say you spent money but it hasn't hit your bank yet. Because you're budget-savvy, you want to factor that spending into your budget.

<<Accounts>>

You can leave the transaction here with a grey checkmark (uncleared) until it clears your bank. At that time, you'll mark it green (cleared).

<<Accounts>>

Awesome job! Let me show you how to delete these hypothetical transactions.

<<Accounts>>

Select the check boxes next to each transaction.
Bye bye, test transactions

<<Accounts>>

Now click the purple text to the right of the search bar that says "2 transactions" and choose Delete.

<<Accounts>>

You did a great job! This will get easier the more transactions you add.
highlight: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

One step down! Here's your progress:
1. Account Tour & Setup
2. How to Add Transactions
3. Budget Tour & Setup
4. Budget Skills
highlight: account_balance
highlight: cleared_status_icon
I clicked into my credit card account

<<Accounts>>

Next up, let's practice adding a transaction on your credit card. Please click on your credit card account to get started!

<<Accounts>>

For credit card transactions, you're going to look at it a little differently. Payments INCREASE the balance and deposits DECREASE the balance. This is because the card balance is negative.

<<Accounts>>

So when you make a purchase that adds to your card balance, the amount spent will be entered as a Payment. Consider this a payment to the merchant.
Done and done

<<Accounts>>

Click "+ Add New" and type "Cell Phone Company" as your Payee.
I've entered the category and $100 spent

<<Accounts>>

For the category, select "Bills." Now, enter $100 in the Payment box.

<<Accounts>>

Finish this transaction by clicking the check mark to turn it green. Then, click "Add." Then click "Cancel" to get out of adding more transactions.

<<Accounts>>

Notice the account balance is red and increases by $100. This is because you still need to pay the credit card bill when it's due.
I've clicked +Add New

<<Accounts>>

Let's pretend to pay this bill from your checking account. Please click "+ Add New" again!

<<Accounts>>

When you're moving money between accounts in MyBudgetCoach, Payee is very important. Click here to see the options.
I selected a transfer from checking

<<Accounts>>

There are two groups: Payees and Transfer To/From. Under the transfer option you'll see your checking account. Please click that for your payee.

<<Accounts>>

Notice you cannot select a category, and the system entered "Transfer." That's because you're simply moving money from checking to pay your credit card bill.
Transaction added!

<<Accounts>>

Please enter $100 in the Deposit box. Then, check the grey box to clear the transaction and click "Add" to finish.

<<Accounts>>

Hooray! You've paid $100 towards this card. The account balance has decreased by $100. Let's see what's happening in your checking account.
I'm in!

<<Accounts>>

Click into your checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Do you see the new transaction? MyBudgetCoach automatically added it to show the $100 taken from this account AND applied to your credit card.

<<Accounts>>

In your checking account, the payee is "to Credit Card." Notice the direction of the arrow before the account name.

<<Accounts>>

This transaction shows $100 subtracted from this account. The only thing left to do is to clear the transaction once it clears in your bank!
Deleted that test transaction

<<Accounts>>

Let's delete these pretend transactions. Go ahead and select the checkbox next to this credit card payment. You'll move your mouse to "1 transactions" and click "Delete" from the drop down menu.
I'm back in my credit card account

<<Accounts>>

One down, one to go. Click back into your credit card account to delete the second transaction we added.

<<Accounts>>

Did you see the credit card payment has been deleted? MyBudgetCoach automatically adds/deletes/changes transactions between accounts.

<<Accounts>>

So if you accidentally enter the wrong amount, you can change that without deleting and re-adding the transaction. It will automatically update in the other account.

<<Accounts>>

Go ahead and delete our Cell Phone Company payment by selecting the checkbox and clicking "Delete."
My accounts are now accurate!

<<Accounts>>

We're back to where we started! Awesome job working through this exercise.

We've spent a lot of time in the accounts section, now it's onto the exciting part!
Click "Budget" in the dark blue column on the left so we can can continue.
Thanks for reminding me

<<Budget>>

Remember, you can take a break at any time. Your progress will be saved and I'll be here when you return!

<<Budget>>

I'll give you a tour of your budget screen next. Here you can see the current month as well as previous and future months.
highlight: months_band
Ooh fancy!

<<Budget>>

Let's say you want to compare several months at once. You can click on the calendars to view one, two, or several months at a time. Please click the different calendar icons to try it out.
highlight: calendar_icons

<<Budget>>

Now you can view multiple months. Let's change the view so you can see a different set of months using the purple selection.
highlight: months_band
I've got the gist

<<Budget>>

I love this feature because you can see what you've spent in past months, and plan ahead for future months. Click a few different months to see the view change.
highlight: calendar_icons
I'm back to the single month view

<<Budget>>

For now, let's keep it in a single month view. Click the first calendar icon.

<<Budget>>

Below the current month, there are several small numbers and one big number.
highlight: budget_header
Deal ðŸ¤

<<Budget>>

While you're getting to know MyBudgetCoach, just focus on the big number for now.

<<Budget>>

Click on this number to see some options for this amount. There are multiple ways to move money around your budget. After all, it's meant to be flexible! Don't worry, if it's negative we will address that soon.
Woo hoo! ðŸŽ‰

You can click anywhere outside of this box to close it. We'll move onto the next part!

guiding_goal = [user_input]

<<Budget>>

We're halfway through setup. At this point you may be wondering what the heck you signed up for. Tell me, what are you hoping to gain from budgeting?

<<Budget>>

Thanks for telling me! That is a great reason to get your finances organized, and I can't wait to show you what budget bliss can look like!
Budget Summary Overview
Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system! You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars accordingly.
highlight: budget_table

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category (envelope). We'll get to customizing these in a bit.
highlight: category_column

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.
highlight: budgeted_column

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent. This gives you true awareness of your spending vs. guessing.
highlight: spent_column

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, that's what you have available.
highlight: balance_column

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover this overspending, you either risk over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card. More on this later!

<<Budget>>

Take a look at those three dots to the right of "Category." This gives you visual options. You can collapse and expand category groups. You can also show and hide Hidden categories.

<<Budget>>

Your budget is made up of categories that organize your dollars. You can have as many (or as few) categories as you'd like.

<<Budget>>

To keep it organized, we house them under Category Groups. These are the darker rows. They may be dark grey or blue depending on if light or dark mode is selected.

<<Budget>>

Your budget is meant to be flexible and change when you need it to! You can collapse groups when you need a focused view, and open them to see the whole picture.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a row, an arrow appears. Here you have options to hide it, rename it or delete it. You can also add a category in this group.

<<Budget>>

Let's try it out. Please rename the first category group to "My Monthly Bills."

<<Budget>>

Now, add a category to this group. Click that arrow again, and add a category. This is just a test run, so no pressure to make it perfect!

<<Budget>>

Each of your categories can be hidden, renamed or deleted with that same arrow. But why would you want something hidden?

<<Budget>>

I use this feature when I need to budget for something, but not regularly. One example is holiday gifts. Once a category is no longer relevant, you can hide it.
Found it.

<<Budget>>

Oh no! It's gone! Don't worry, it's easy to retrieve. Click the three dots and select "Toggle Hidden."

<<Budget>>

There it is! It's greyed out, indicating it's hidden. 
Another important note: you cannot delete categories that have previous transactions linked to it. You will be prompted to re-label those transactions in order to actually delete the category.
It's back in action

<<Budget>>

Let's bring this category back into play. Hovering over the name, click on the arrow and select "Show."
It's hidden

<<Budget>>

This keeps the data so you can reference it. You can then unhide the category the next time you need to use it. Go ahead and hide the category you just added.
Ready coach!

<<Budget>>

Does this mean you need to be a perfect budgeter? Not at all! You're going to have areas where you spend more than you expect. You may also have categories with leftover money at the end of the month.
I'm feeling a bit overwhelmed.<br style="border-color: var(--border-color);">overwhelmed = feeling_overwhelmed
Phew, ok!

<<Budget>>

Thank you for sharing that with me. Deep breath! You can always take a break and come back, or book a call if you'd like more support from me.
Let's do this!

I'm great!
overwhelmed = feeling_good
Mind blown ðŸ¤¯

<<Budget>>

Just like magic! ðŸª„ Let's get to know your new organizational system.

<<Budget>>

The first category group consists of your regular monthly bills. These are bills with:
1) a set amount 
2) a set due date
The exception would be utilities, which may fluctuate in amount. However they're still due on the same day each month.

<<Budget>>

Next we have Monthly Expenses. These expenses occur every month, but the amounts and spending dates fluctuate. It's not likely you spend the same amount month after month.

<<Budget>>

The third category group is Variable Expenses. Sometimes you spend on these categories, and sometimes you don't!

<<Budget>>

You'll notice these category groups are organized by priority. I want you to look at your budget and know exactly what your dollars need to do before payday.
Thanks for the reminder!

<<Budget>>

I'm happy to hear that! If at any point you become overwhelmed, you can always take a break or book a call for more support.

<<Budget>>

I have hypothetical categories and due dates listed. They're ordered chronologically. So if you get paid again on the 15th, you can see exactly which bills you need to fund with the money you have now.
I put it back where it belongs

<<Budget>>

But look! The water bill should be above the electric bill. You can simply click and drag to move it where it belongs. Try it now!

<<Budget>>

Now it's your turn! Look at this template and see what is relevant to you. Please rename these categories or delete the ones that aren't relevant.
I'm done!

<<Budget>>

It will be helpful to know due dates and amounts, but they can be added later. I'll be here in the corner when you're ready to move on. Remember you can click the X and I'll hide in the left column if I get in your way.
Done with the others!

<<Budget>>

That was quick! You're really catching on. I want you to do the same thing with the other two category groups.
Ok, I'll rein it in. ðŸ´

<<Budget>>

You may be thinking of big ideas to expand your budget. I recommend keeping it short and sweet while you're learning, but you can add more any time.

<<Budget>>

You just created the envelopes to budget all of the dollars in your checking account. Awesome!
Budget Setup
Budget Skills
Tell me more!

<<Budget>>

Chances are, you've set up a budget before. You may be feeling skeptical. The magic of MyBudgetCoach is in the tools and flexibility.

<<Budget>>

Think about this: what does your money need to accomplish before you get paid again?
highlight: budget_header

<<Budget>>

Good! Next we'll budget dollars into the categories below. There are a few ways to do this. For the first move, click the purple number and select "Move to a Category."
Money moved!

<<Budget>>

Enter a dollar amount, and then select a category from the dropdown menu. Click "Transfer." Don't worry, this is just transferring money from your big pile into an envelope (category) below. Nothing actually moves in your bank accounts.
I'm a tech wizard ðŸ§™

<<Budget>>

My personal favorite way to budget money is to click into the "Budgeted" column. Think of this like a spreadsheet. Pick a category to fund and click into the "Budgeted" cell for that row. Then simply type how much you want in there.

<<Budget>>

The last way you can move money around is between categories. Let's say you want to move dollars from one category to another directly.
An example of this would be when you need some extra money for the coffee shop, and plan to take it from your Grocery envelope.
highlight: balance_column
Been there before
Let's get that latte â˜•ï¸

<<Budget>>

Start by clicking on the dollars budgeted. Then, click "Transfer to Another Category." Enter the amount you want to move and select a new category. Finalize this with the purple button, "Transfer."

Note: for this to work, you have to have assigned some money into one category before you can transfer it to another.
No money left behind

<<Budget>>

Score! Those are the three ways to move money around. It's time to put the rest of your dollars to work. MyBudgetCoach is a zero-based system, so be sure not to leave any money in "To Budget."

<<Budget>>

The system will make it clear when you have overspent and ask you to take money from another category to cover it. That can be tough to see, but it reveals your true financial situation.
I did it!

<<Budget>>

Drumroll please....you've completed the tutorial! ðŸ¥ Reward yourself for your amazing progress!

<<Budget>>

So what now? It's time to put these new skills to the test. budget all of your dollars and start entering transactions as you spend.

When you have a balance on that credit card, you will see a red number in the Spent column (gasp!). Even if you could pay it off in full, you haven't budgeted money to that goal yet. You have debt and MyBudgetCoach wants you to address it.

<<Budget>>

The red is intentional. It's supposed to make you uncomfortable so that you can see your true financial picture. It won't stay that way, but I have a question first.
I'm planning to pay it in full

Um, hold on! That's AMAZING! You get all of those credit card perks without any of that pesky interest! I'm so proud!

Good to know! Whether you're planning to pay in full each month or chip away at debt slowly, MyBudgetCoach can work for you.
I'm going to make minimum payments

<<Budget>>

If something changes in the future and you can't pay it in full each month, MyBudgetCoach can still work for you. You will just have a slightly different approach in the program. If that happens, I recommend booking a call.

<<Budget>>

To budget money from your Checking account (positive) to your Credit Card (negative), you'll type the red number into the Budgeted column. This zeroes it out and the red number goes away. Now, you can budget the rest of your dollars knowing that your full credit card bill is accounted for.
Yep, I want to know where my money is going!

<<Budget>>

You're going to want to categorize your credit card purchases differently to track the data. You won't be categorizing transactions as "ðŸ’³ Credit Card 1 Starting Balance" beyond this exercise.

<<Budget>>

Think of your credit card as an extension of your checking account, with one extra step. If you spend $50 for groceries on your credit card, the overspending (red) will be in the Groceries category. Once you budget dollars to it, the red goes away. That means you have $50 towards your credit card bill.

<<Budget>>

With this method, as long as you budget money to envelopes to cover overspending you will be able to pay your credit card bill in full. If you're starting with debt, that's ok! The first step to get out of debt is to stop digging.

Next up, let's practice adding a transaction on your credit card. Please click on your credit card account to get started!

For credit card transactions, you're going to look at it a little differently. Payments INCREASE the balance and deposits DECREASE the balance. This is because the card balance is negative.

<<Accounts>>

So when you make a purchase that adds to your card balance, the amount spent will be entered as a Payment. Consider this a payment to the merchant.

Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system! You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars accordingly.
highlight: budget_table

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category. We'll get customizing these in a bit.
highlight: budget_category_group

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.
highlight: budgeted_column

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent. This gives you true awareness of your spending vs. guessing.
highlight: spent_column

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, that's what you have available.
highlight: balance_column

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover this overspending, you either risk over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card. More on this later!

<<Budget>>

Does this mean you need to be a perfect budgeter? Not at all! You're going to have areas where you spend more than you expect. You may also have categories with leftover money at the end of the month.

<<Budget>>

<<Budget>>

Your budget is made up of categories that organize your dollars. You can have as many (or as few) categories as you'd like.

<<Budget>>

Your budget is meant to be flexible and change when you need it to! You can collapse groups when you need a focused view, and open them to see the whole picture.

<<Budget>>

<<Budget>>

To budget money from your Checking account (positive) to your Credit Card (negative), you'll type the red number into the Budgeted column. This zeroes it out and the red number goes away. Now, you can budget the rest of your dollars knowing that your credit card bill is accounted for.
highlight: center_screen

You're going to want to categorize your credit card purchases differently to track the data. You won't be categorizing transactions as "Credit Card 1" beyond this exercise.

<<Budget>>

Think of your credit card as an extension of your checking account, with one extra step. If you spend $50 for groceries on your credit card, the overspending (red) will be in the Groceries category. Once you budget dollars to it, the red goes away. That means you have $50 towards your credit card bill.

<<Budget>>

With this method, as long as you budget money to envelopes to cover overspending you will be able to pay your credit card bill in full.
